user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_suspend_connection:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_suspend_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Cannot suspend connections without " \
                  "enabling MHD_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME!\n"));
#ifdef UPGRADE_SUPPORT
  if (NULL != connection->urh)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Error: connection scheduled for \"upgrade\" cannot " \
                 "be suspended.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    return;
  }
#endif /* UPGRADE_SUPPORT */
  internal_suspend_connection_ (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
explanation: I have selected fragments that can give rise to unreachable-code concerns and therefore should be investigated: the assertion block (may be compiled out or evaluate to a constant), the conditional that invokes MHD_PANIC (MHD_PANIC may be a non-returning termination routine), the UPGRADE_SUPPORT block (contains an early return that makes subsequent code unreachable on that path, and the logging is conditional on HAVE_MESSAGES), and the final call to internal_suspend_connection_ (this call could be unreachable if the preceding panic or return paths are non-returning or always taken). Other parts of the function (the function header, the local daemon declaration, and ordinary control flow outside the indicated conditional/conditional-compilation blocks) are standard and reachable in at least some execution/configuration scenarios, so they do not need to be investigated for MISRA Rule 2.1 issues here.
